TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Loamy-skeletal, isotic Entic Haplocryods

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Nambe loam, spruce forest.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
01--2 to 1 inch; decomposed organic matter consisting principally of needles, twigs and bark.
02--1 inch to 0; partially decomposed organic matter.
A1--0 to 3 inches; very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) loam, very dark brown (10YR 2/2) moist; moderate fine crumb structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; many fine and medium roots; many very fine to medium pores; approximately 10 percent stones; very strongly acid (pH 5.0); clear smooth boundary.  (1 to 4 inches thick)
A2--3 to 8 inches; brown (7.5YR 5/4) loam, dark brown (7.5YR 4/2) moist; weak fine and medium subangular blocky structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; common medium and fine roots; many fine to medium pores; approximately 15 percent stones; very strongly acid (pH 4.4); clear wavy boundary.  (4 to 6 inches thick)
B21ir--8 to 18 inches; light brown (7.5YR 6/4) sandy loam, brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; few fine roots; common fine pores; approximately 30 percent stones; undersides of the stones have dark coatings presumed to be humus and iron oxides; very strongly acid (pH 5.0); gradual wavy boundary.  (8 to 14 inches thick)
B22ir--18 to 24 inches; light brown (7.5YR 6/4) sandy loam, brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist; weak fine subangular blocky structure; hard, friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; few fine roots; few fine pores; approximately 60 percent stones; the stones have reddish brown coatings presumed to be humus and iron oxides; cementation in places; very strongly acid (pH 5.0); gradual wavy boundary.  (5 to 12 inches thick)
C--24 to 60 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) sandy loam, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; massive; slightly hard, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; approximately 60 percent stones; very strongly acid (pH 5.0).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Santa Fe County, New Mexico; NW1/4 NE1/4 section 15, T.18N., R.11E.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The solum is 18 to 36 inches thick.  The soil is extremely acid to strongly acid (pH 4.0 to 5.5).  Base saturation ranges from 5 to 20 percent.  The mean annual soil temperature is about 33 degrees F. and the mean summer soil temperature is about 46 degrees F.  Surface textures are loam and sandy loam with 0 to 20 percent gravel and cobbles.  Stones range from 30 to 50 percent in the upper part of the solum and from 50 to 80 percent in the lower part of the solum and in the C horizon.
The A1 horizon has hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value of 3 through 5 dry, 2 or 3 moist, and chroma of 1 through 3.  The A2 horizon has hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value of 5 through 7 dry, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 2 through 4.
The B21ir horizon has hue of 7.5YR or 5YR, value of 4 through 6 dry, 3 through 4.5 moist, and chroma of 2 through 4.  The B22ir horizon has hue of 7.5YR through 2.5YR, value of 5 or 6 dry, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 3 through 5.  The B21ir and B22ir horizons are typically sandy loam but range in clay from 6 to 15 percent, in silt from 5 to 30 percent, and in sand from 55 to 80 percent.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Bensley, Crabtree, Endlich, Grenadier, Halleck, Holderman, Oatman and Valsetz series.  Bensley, Grenadier and Halleck soils have 18 to 35 percent clay in the B2 horizon.  Crabtree soils have mottles with chroma of 2 or less within depths of 20 to 30 inches.  Endlich, Holderman and Valsetz soils have bedrock at depths of less than 40 inches.  Oatman soils are slightly acid in the upper part of the solum and medium acid in the lower part.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Nambe soils are on mountain sideslopes at elevations of 10,000 feet and above.  They formed in very strongly to strongly acid glacial till or slope wash sediments derived from granite, gneiss and schist.  Slopes range from less than 20 percent to 100 percent.  The average annual precipitation on these soils range from about 38 to 50 inches and the average annual summer temperature is about 43 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Bobtail and Penitente soils.  Bobtail soils are coarse, loamy.  Penitente soils have an umbric epipedon and are pergelic.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; very rapid runoff; moderately rapid permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Timber production, watershed and recreation are the chief uses.  The native vegetation is Engelmann spruce, subalpine fir, geranium, pussytoes, sedge and brome.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Mountainous areas at high elevations in northern New Mexico.  These soils are inextensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content:
SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Santa Fe County (Santa Fe Area), New Mexico, 1970.
MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana
DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Mountainous areas at high elevations in northern New Mexico.  These soils are inextensive.
USE AND VEGETATION:  Timber production, watershed and recreation are the chief uses.  The native vegetation is Engelmann spruce, subalpine fir, geranium, pussytoes, sedge and brome.
DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; very rapid runoff; moderately rapid permeability.
GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Bobtail and Penitente soils.  Bobtail soils are coarse, loamy.  Penitente soils have an umbric epipedon and are pergelic.
GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Nambe soils are on mountain sideslopes at elevations of 10,000 feet and above.  They formed in very strongly to strongly acid glacial till or slope wash sediments derived from granite, gneiss and schist.  Slopes range from less than 20 percent to 100 percent.  The average annual precipitation on these soils range from about 38 to 50 inches and the average annual summer temperature is about 43 degrees F.
COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Bensley, Crabtree, Endlich, Grenadier, Halleck, Holderman, Oatman and Valsetz series.  Bensley, Grenadier and Halleck soils have 18 to 35 percent clay in the B2 horizon.  Crabtree soils have mottles with chroma of 2 or less within depths of 20 to 30 inches.  Endlich, Holderman and Valsetz soils have bedrock at depths of less than 40 inches.  Oatman soils are slightly acid in the upper part of the solum and medium acid in the lower part.
The B21ir horizon has hue of 7.5YR or 5YR, value of 4 through 6 dry, 3 through 4.5 moist, and chroma of 2 through 4.  The B22ir horizon has hue of 7.5YR through 2.5YR, value of 5 or 6 dry, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 3 through 5.  The B21ir and B22ir horizons are typically sandy loam but range in clay from 6 to 15 percent, in silt from 5 to 30 percent, and in sand from 55 to 80 percent.
The A1 horizon has hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value of 3 through 5 dry, 2 or 3 moist, and chroma of 1 through 3.  The A2 horizon has hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value of 5 through 7 dry, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 2 through 4.
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The solum is 18 to 36 inches thick.  The soil is extremely acid to strongly acid (pH 4.0 to 5.5).  Base saturation ranges from 5 to 20 percent.  The mean annual soil temperature is about 33 degrees F. and the mean summer soil temperature is about 46 degrees F.  Surface textures are loam and sandy loam with 0 to 20 percent gravel and cobbles.  Stones range from 30 to 50 percent in the upper part of the solum and from 50 to 80 percent in the lower part of the solum and in the C horizon.
TYPE LOCATION:  Santa Fe County, New Mexico; NW1/4 NE1/4 section 15, T.18N., R.11E.
C--24 to 60 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) sandy loam, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; massive; slightly hard, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; approximately 60 percent stones; very strongly acid (pH 5.0).
B22ir--18 to 24 inches; light brown (7.5YR 6/4) sandy loam, brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist; weak fine subangular blocky structure; hard, friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; few fine roots; few fine pores; approximately 60 percent stones; the stones have reddish brown coatings presumed to be humus and iron oxides; cementation in places; very strongly acid (pH 5.0); gradual wavy boundary.  (5 to 12 inches thick)
B21ir--8 to 18 inches; light brown (7.5YR 6/4) sandy loam, brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; few fine roots; common fine pores; approximately 30 percent stones; undersides of the stones have dark coatings presumed to be humus and iron oxides; very strongly acid (pH 5.0); gradual wavy boundary.  (8 to 14 inches thick)
A2--3 to 8 inches; brown (7.5YR 5/4) loam, dark brown (7.5YR 4/2) moist; weak fine and medium subangular blocky structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; common medium and fine roots; many fine to medium pores; approximately 15 percent stones; very strongly acid (pH 4.4); clear wavy boundary.  (4 to 6 inches thick)
A1--0 to 3 inches; very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) loam, very dark brown (10YR 2/2) moist; moderate fine crumb structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; many fine and medium roots; many very fine to medium pores; approximately 10 percent stones; very strongly acid (pH 5.0); clear smooth boundary.  (1 to 4 inches thick)
02--1 inch to 0; partially decomposed organic matter.
01--2 to 1 inch; decomposed organic matter consisting principally of needles, twigs and bark.
TYPICAL PEDON:  Nambe loam, spruce forest.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
TAXONOMIC CLASS: Loamy-skeletal, isotic Entic Haplocryods
The Nambre series consists of deep, well drained soils that formed in material derived from granite, gneiss and schist.  Nambre soils are on mountain sideslopes and have slopes of 20 to 100 percent.  The mean annual precipitation is about 44 inches and the mean annual air temperature is about 32 degrees F.
NAMBE SERIES
03/1999
